articles.headline: Widening Highways Doesn’t Fix Traffic. So Why Do We Keep Doing It?
articles.snippet: With billions of dollars available to improve transportation infrastructure, states have a chance to try new strategies for addressing congestion. But some habits are hard to break.
articles.abstract: With billions of dollars available to improve transportation infrastructure, states have a chance to try new strategies for addressing congestion. But some habits are hard to break.
articles.lead_paragraph: Interstate 710 in Los Angeles is, like the city itself, famous for its traffic. Freight trucks traveling between the city and the port of Long Beach, along with commuters, clog the highway. The trucks idle in the congestion, contributing to poor air quality in surrounding neighborhoods that are home to over one million people.
articles.byline: By Eden Weingart and Alyssa Schukar

articles.headline: A New Area of A.I. Booms, Even Amid the Tech Gloom
articles.snippet: An investment frenzy over “generative artificial intelligence” has gripped Silicon Valley, as tools that generate text, images and sounds in response to short prompts seize the imagination.
articles.abstract: An investment frenzy over “generative artificial intelligence” has gripped Silicon Valley, as tools that generate text, images and sounds in response to short prompts seize the imagination.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five weeks ago, OpenAI, a San Francisco artificial intelligence lab, released ChatGPT, a chatbot that answers questions in clear, concise prose. The A.I.-powered tool immediately caused a sensation, with more than a million people using it to create everything from poetry to high school term papers to rewrites of Queen songs.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Speaker Drama Raises New Fears on Debt Limit
articles.snippet: An emboldened conservative flank and concessions made to win votes could lead to a protracted standoff on critical fiscal issues, risking economic pain.
articles.abstract: An emboldened conservative flank and concessions made to win votes could lead to a protracted standoff on critical fiscal issues, risking economic pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California finally secured the House speakership in a dramatic vote ending around 12:30 a.m. Saturday, but the dysfunction in his party and the deal he struck to win over holdout Republicans also raised the risks of persistent political gridlock that could destabilize the American financial system.

articles.headline: The Hottest Gen Z Gadget Is a 20-Year-Old Digital Camera
articles.snippet: Young people are opting for point-and-shoots and blurry photos.
articles.abstract: Young people are opting for point-and-shoots and blurry photos.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, Anthony Tabarez celebrated prom like many of today’s high schoolers: dancing the night away and capturing it through photos and videos. The snapshots show Mr. Tabarez, 18, and his friends grinning, jumping around and waving their arms from a crowded dance floor.

articles.headline: As Asian Societies Age, ‘Retirement’ Just Means More Work
articles.snippet: Across East Asia, populations are graying faster than anywhere else in the world, and while younger generations shrink, older workers are often toiling well into their 70s and beyond.
articles.abstract: Across East Asia, populations are graying faster than anywhere else in the world, and while younger generations shrink, older workers are often toiling well into their 70s and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — All Yoshihito Oonami wants to do is retire and give his worn body a rest.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida

articles.headline: From Gingrich to McCarthy, the Roots of Governance by Chaos
articles.snippet: Mr. Gingrich began the zero-sum politics that mutated into the brand of the Tea Party and Trump M.A.G.A. Republicans and that presaged the raucous speaker battle in the House.
articles.abstract: Mr. Gingrich began the zero-sum politics that mutated into the brand of the Tea Party and Trump M.A.G.A. Republicans and that presaged the raucous speaker battle in the House.

articles.headline: In Speaker Fight’s Final Hours, Arm-Twisting, Flaring Tempers and Calls From Trump
articles.snippet: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s slog to his post ended with a remarkably public show of intraparty strife that played out in a history-making overnight session.
articles.abstract: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s slog to his post ended with a remarkably public show of intraparty strife that played out in a history-making overnight session.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Confident that he was about to win the speaker’s gavel after a torturous four-day stretch of defeats, Representative Kevin McCarthy of California sat grinning late Friday night in his chair on the House floor. Then his face dropped.

articles.headline: As China Lifts Pandemic Border Controls, Mixed Feelings at Home and Abroad
articles.snippet: Friends and families are planning reunions; tourists are booking flights. But amid the anticipation, there’s a whiff of anxiety.
articles.abstract: Friends and families are planning reunions; tourists are booking flights. But amid the anticipation, there’s a whiff of anxiety.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Over the past three years, Zhou Wanhui, a Hong Kong resident, has visited her parents in China just three times. Though they live only two hours away by train, Covid restrictions made it so difficult to cross the Hong Kong border into mainland China that one of Ms. Zhou’s trips included a three-hour flight to Shanghai and nearly a month of quarantine in two cities.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Tiffany May

articles.headline: A Lecturer Showed a Painting of the Prophet Muhammad. She Lost Her Job.
articles.snippet: After an outcry over the art history class by Muslim students, Hamline University officials said the incident was Islamophobic. But many scholars say the work is a masterpiece.
articles.abstract: After an outcry over the art history class by Muslim students, Hamline University officials said the incident was Islamophobic. But many scholars say the work is a masterpiece.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Case Closed! Old-School Police and Court Shows Are Big Streaming Hits.
articles.snippet: Prestige shows like “The White Lotus” grab a lot of the headlines and rave reviews. But viewers still like to settle in with the familiar.
articles.abstract: Prestige shows like “The White Lotus” grab a lot of the headlines and rave reviews. But viewers still like to settle in with the familiar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, it looked as though shows in which a group of characters confront and neatly resolve a crime or a court case in a single episode, a staple of TV since its earliest days, might not make the leap to the streaming future.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Bridge to Nowhere
articles.snippet: The tech giant had already remade the virtual world. For a brief period, it also tried to make it easier for people in the Bay Area to get to work. Then it gave up.
articles.abstract: The tech giant had already remade the virtual world. For a brief period, it also tried to make it easier for people in the Bay Area to get to work. Then it gave up.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early summer of 2017, Warren Slocum walked into a warehouse in Menlo Park, Calif., to meet with members of Facebook’s staff and was mesmerized.

articles.headline: Now Fighting for Ukraine: Volunteers Seeking Revenge Against Russia
articles.snippet: Chechens, Crimean Tatars and people from the former Soviet republics, all with deep historical grievances against Moscow, are eagerly taking up arms for Kyiv.
articles.abstract: Chechens, Crimean Tatars and people from the former Soviet republics, all with deep historical grievances against Moscow, are eagerly taking up arms for Kyiv.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV REGION, Ukraine — The sharp crack of sniper fire rang out across the snowbound valley. Soldiers in white camouflage crouched low, shooting at the hill opposite to provide cover as four men evacuated a casualty.

articles.headline: Biden Visits Southern Border Amid Fresh Crackdown on Migrants
articles.snippet: A surge of migration has made El Paso one of the most vivid symbols of the decades-long breakdown in America’s immigration system.
articles.abstract: A surge of migration has made El Paso one of the most vivid symbols of the decades-long breakdown in America’s immigration system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Biden’s visit to Mexico to meet North American leaders.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Edgar Sandoval

articles.headline: Republicans Prepare New Rules, but Fixing Congress Isn’t So Easy
articles.snippet: History suggests that the procedural plans of the new House Republican majority are likely to lead to more gridlock and legislative instability, not less.
articles.abstract: History suggests that the procedural plans of the new House Republican majority are likely to lead to more gridlock and legislative instability, not less.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Smarting after a dozen years under iron-fisted Republican rule, House Democrats promised to do things differently and open up the institution when they regained majority control in 2007.

articles.headline: Bolsonaro Supporters Lay Siege to Brazil’s Capital
articles.snippet: Backers of former President Jair Bolsonaro ransacked government offices, denouncing what they falsely claim was a rigged election. Hundreds were arrested.
articles.abstract: Backers of former President Jair Bolsonaro ransacked government offices, denouncing what they falsely claim was a rigged election. Hundreds were arrested.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on Brazil’s anti-democracy riots.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

articles.headline: In Power With Netanyahu, Ultra-Orthodox Parties Chart Israel’s Future
articles.snippet: Bolstered by growth in numbers and political influence, ultra-Orthodox parties are pushing for greater autonomy, with potentially far-reaching implications for the country.
articles.abstract: Bolstered by growth in numbers and political influence, ultra-Orthodox parties are pushing for greater autonomy, with potentially far-reaching implications for the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — To preserve his new government, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is making significant concessions to far-right political parties on Palestinian issues, judicial independence and police powers, but also less noticed moves on behalf of another key member of his coalition: parties that represent the fast-growing ultra-Orthodox public.

articles.headline: A Korean War Wall of Remembrance Set Hundreds of Errors in Stone
articles.snippet: Many names of American service members who died in the conflict are misspelled or missing from the new memorial wall in Washington, relatives and researchers say.
articles.abstract: Many names of American service members who died in the conflict are misspelled or missing from the new memorial wall in Washington, relatives and researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Britain’s Economic Health Is Withering With Sick Workers on the Sidelines
articles.snippet: Many people who want to work can’t because of long-term health problems, a persistent issue that is causing Britain’s economy to go “into reverse.”
articles.abstract: Many people who want to work can’t because of long-term health problems, a persistent issue that is causing Britain’s economy to go “into reverse.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Christina Barratt was used to the 12- to 14-hour days. For years, she would get into her car each morning and set out to department stores and other retailers all over northwest England, selling greeting cards for a large manufacturer.

articles.headline: Without Hesitation, Ukraine Goes Toe to Toe With Russia in Bakhmut
articles.snippet: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
articles.abstract: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — It was midmorning last Friday when the camera of a Ukrainian drone zoomed in on a Russian soldier moving furtively among trees on the edge of town. Another enemy assault was underway in the eastern city of Bakhmut.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
